column2: Mr and Mrs Boffin sat after breakfast, in the Bower, a prey to prosperity.

column2: Many disordered papers were before him, and he looked at them about as hopefully as an innocent civilian might look at a crowd of troops whom he was required at five minutes' notice to manoeuvre and review.

column2: He had been engaged in some attempts to make notes of these papers; but being troubled (as men of his stamp often are) with an exceedingly distrustful and corrective thumb, that busy member had so often interposed to smear his notes, that they were little more legible than the various impressions of itself; which blurred his nose and forehead.

column2: It is curious to consider, in such a case as Mr Boffin's, what a cheap article ink is, and how far it may be made to go.

column2: As a grain of musk will scent a drawer for many years, and still lose nothing appreciable of its original weight, so a halfpenny-worth of ink would blot Mr Boffin to the roots of his hair and the calves of his legs, without inscribing a line on the paper before him, or appearing to diminish in the inkstand.

column2: Mr Boffin was in such severe literary difficulties that his eyes were prominent and fixed, and his breathing was stertorous, when, to the great relief of Mrs Boffin, who observed these symptoms with alarm, the yard bell rang.

column2: Well, sir, I am rather unprepared to see you, for, to tell you the truth, I've been so busy with one thing and another, that I've not had time to turn your offer over.'

column2: 'It rather puzzled me at the time,' said Mr Boffin, 'and it rather puzzled me and Mrs Boffin when we spoke of it afterwards, because (not to make a mystery of our belief) we have always believed a Secretary to be a piece of furniture, mostly of mahogany, lined with green baize or leather, with a lot of little drawers in it.

column2: Relinquishing his hat and gloves, Mr Rokesmith sat down quietly at the table, arranged the open papers into an orderly heap, cast his eyes over each in succession, folded it, docketed it on the outside, laid it in a second heap, and, when that second heap was complete and the first gone, took from his pocket a piece of string and tied it together with a remarkably dexterous hand at a running curve and a loop.

column2: 'And I tell you, my deary,' said Mrs Boffin, 'that if you don't close with Mr Rokesmith now at once, and if you ever go a muddling yourself again with things never meant nor made for you, you'll have an apoplexy--besides iron-moulding your linen--and you'll break my heart.'

column2: Whatever is built by man for man's occupation, must, like natural creations, fulfil the intention of its existence, or soon perish.

column2: This old house had wasted--more from desuetude than it would have wasted from use, twenty years for one.

column2: A certain leanness falls upon houses not sufficiently imbued with life (as if they were nourished upon it), which was very noticeable here. The staircase, balustrades, and rails, had a spare look--an air of being denuded to the bone--which the panels of the walls and the jambs of the doors and windows also bore.

column2: There was the old grisly four-post bedstead, without hangings, and with a jail-like upper rim of iron and spikes; and there was the old patch-work counterpane.

column2: There was the tight-clenched old bureau, receding atop like a bad and secret forehead; there was the cumbersome old table with twisted legs, at the bed-side; and there was the box upon it, in which the will had lain.

column2: 'Touched them?'
column3: 'Touched them?'

column2: 'No. Felt them in the air.
column3: 'no Felt them in the air.

column2: I was sorting those things on the chest, and not thinking of the old man or the children, but singing to myself, when all in a moment I felt there was a face growing out of the dark.'
column3: I was sorting those things on the chest, and not thinking of the old man or the children, but singing to myself, when all in a moment I felt there was a face growing out of the dark.'

column2: 'What face?' asked her husband, looking about him.
column3: 'What face?' asked her husband, looking about him.

column2: 'For a moment it was the old man's, and then it got younger.
column3: 'For a moment it was the old man's, and then it got younger.

column2: For a moment it was both the children's, and then it got older.
column3: For a moment it was both the children's, and then it got older.

column2: For a moment it was a strange face, and then it was all the faces.'
column3: For a moment it was a strange face, and then it was all the faces.'

column2: 'And then it was gone?'
column3: 'And then it was gone?'

column2: 'Yes; and then it was gone.'
column3: 'Yes; and then it was gone.'

column2: 'Where were you then, old lady?'
column3: 'Where were you then, old lady?'

column2: 'Here, at the chest.
column3: 'Here, at the chest.

column2: Well; I got the better of it, and went on sorting, and went on singing to myself.
column3: Well; I got the better of it, and went on sorting, and went on singing to myself.

column2: Lor! I says, "I'll think of something else--something comfortable--and put it out of my head." So I thought of the new house and Miss Bella Wilfer, and was thinking at a great rate with that sheet there in my hand, when all of a sudden, the faces seemed to be hidden in among the folds of it and I let it drop.'
column3: Lor! I says, "I'll think of something else-something comfortable-and put it out of my head." So I thought of the new house and Miss Bella Wilfer, and was thinking at a great rate with that sheet there in my hand, when all of a sudden, the faces seemed to be hidden in among the folds of it and I let it drop.'

column2: As it still lay on the floor where it had fallen, Mr Boffin picked it up and laid it on the chest.
column3: As it still lay on the floor where it had fallen, Mr Boffin picked it up and laid it on the chest.

column2: 'And then you ran down stairs?'
column3: 'And then you ran down stairs?'

column2: 'No.
column3: 'no

column2: I thought I'd try another room, and shake it off.
column3: I thought I'd try another room, and shake it off.

column2: I says to myself, "I'll go and walk slowly up and down the old man's room three times, from end to end, and then I shall have conquered it." I went in with the candle in my hand; but the moment I came near the bed, the air got thick with them.'
column3: I says to myself, "I'll go and walk slowly up and down the old man's room three times, from end to end, and then I shall have conquered it." I went in with the candle in my hand; but the moment I came near the bed, the air got thick with them.'

column2: 'With the faces?'
column3: 'With the faces?'

column2: 'Yes, and I even felt that they were in the dark behind the side-door, and on the little staircase, floating away into the yard.
column3: 'Yes, and I even felt that they were in the dark behind the side door, and on the little staircase, floating away into the yard.

column2: Then, I called you.'
column3: Then, I called you.'

column2: Mr Boffin, lost in amazement, looked at Mrs Boffin.
column3: Mr Boffin, lost in amazement, looked at Mrs Boffin.

column2: Mrs Boffin, lost in her own fluttered inability to make this out, looked at Mr Boffin.
column3: Mrs Boffin, lost in her own fluttered inability to make this out, looked at Mr Boffin.

column2: 'I think, my dear,' said the Golden Dustman, 'I'll at once get rid of Wegg for the night, because he's coming to inhabit the Bower, and it might be put into his head or somebody else's, if he heard this and it got about that the house is haunted.
column3: 'I think, my dear,' said the Golden Dustman, 'I'll at once get rid of Wegg for the night, because he's coming to inhabit the Bower, and it might be put into his head or somebody else's, if he heard this and it got about that the house is haunted.

column2: Whereas we know better.
column3: Whereas we know better.

column2: Don't we?'
column3: Don't we?'

column2: 'I never had the feeling in the house before,' said Mrs Boffin; 'and I have been about it alone at all hours of the night.
column3: 'I never had the feeling in the house before,' said Mrs Boffin; 'and I have been about it alone at all hours of the night.

column2: I have been in the house when Death was in it, and I have been in the house when Murder was a new part of its adventures, and I never had a fright in it yet.'
column3: I have been in the house when Death was in it, and I have been in the house when Murder was a new part of its adventures, and I never had a fright in it yet.'

column2: 'And won't again, my dear,' said Mr Boffin. 'Depend upon it, it comes of thinking and dwelling on that dark spot.'
column3: 'And won't again, my dear,' said Mr Boffin. 'Depend upon it, it comes of thinking and dwelling on that dark spot.'

column2: 'Yes; but why didn't it come before?' asked Mrs Boffin.
column3: 'Yes; but why didn't it come before?' asked Mrs Boffin.

column2: This draft on Mr Boffin's philosophy could only be met by that gentleman with the remark that everything that is at all, must begin at some time. Then, tucking his wife's arm under his own, that she might not be left by herself to be troubled again, he descended to release Wegg.
column3: This draft on Mr Boffin's philosophy could only be met by that gentleman with the remark that everything that is at all, must begin at some time. Then, tucking his wife's arm under his own, that she might not be left by herself to be troubled again, he descended to release Wegg.

column2: Who, being something drowsy after his plentiful repast, and constitutionally of a shirking temperament, was well enough pleased to stump away, without doing what he had come to do, and was paid for doing.
column3: Who, being something drowsy after his plentiful repast, and constitutionally of a shirking temperament, was well enough pleased to stump away, without doing what he had come to do, and was paid for doing.

column2: Mr Boffin then put on his hat, and Mrs Boffin her shawl; and the pair, further provided with a bunch of keys and a lighted lantern, went all over the dismal house--dismal everywhere, but in their own two rooms--from cellar to cock-loft.
column3: Mr Boffin then put on his hat, and Mrs Boffin her shawl; and the pair, further provided with a bunch of keys and a lighted lantern, went all over the dismal house-dismal everywhere, but in their own two rooms-from cellar to cock loft.

column2: Not resting satisfied with giving that much chace to Mrs Boffin's fancies, they pursued them into the yard and outbuildings, and under the Mounds.
column3: Not resting satisfied with giving that much chace to Mrs Boffin's fancies, they pursued them into the yard and outbuildings, and under the Mounds.

column2: And setting the lantern, when all was done, at the foot of one of the Mounds, they comfortably trotted to and fro for an evening walk, to the end that the murky cobwebs in Mrs Boffin's brain might be blown away.
column3: And setting the lantern, when all was done, at the foot of one of the Mounds, they comfortably trotted to and fro for an evening walk, to the end that the murky cobwebs in Mrs Boffin's brain might be blown away.

column2: 'There, my dear!' said Mr Boffin when they came in to supper.
column3: 'There, my dear!' said Mr Boffin when they came in to supper.

column2: 'That was the treatment, you see.
column3: 'That was the treatment, you see.

column2: Completely worked round, haven't you?'
column3: Completely worked round, haven't you?'

column2: 'Yes, deary,' said Mrs Boffin, laying aside her shawl.
column3: 'Yes, deary,' said Mrs Boffin, laying aside her shawl.

column2: 'I'm not nervous any more.
column3: 'I'm not nervous any more.

column2: I'm not a bit troubled now.
column3: I'm not a bit troubled now.

column2: I'd go anywhere about the house the same as ever.
column3: I'd go anywhere about the house the same as ever.

column2: But--'
column3: But-'

column2: 'Eh!' said Mr Boffin.
column3: 'Eh!' said Mr Boffin.

column2: 'But I've only to shut my eyes.'
column3: 'But I've only to shut my eyes.'

column2: 'And what then?'
column3: 'And what then?'

column2: 'Why then,' said Mrs Boffin, speaking with her eyes closed, and her left hand thoughtfully touching her brow, 'then, there they are!
column3: 'Why then,' said Mrs Boffin, speaking with her eyes closed, and her left hand thoughtfully touching her brow, 'then, there they are!

column2: The old man's face, and it gets younger.
column3: The old man's face, and it gets younger.

column2: The two children's faces, and they get older.
column3: The two children's faces, and they get older.

column2: A face that I don't know.
column3: A face that I don't know.

column2: And then all the faces!'
column3: And then all the faces!'

column2: Opening her eyes again, and seeing her husband's face across the table, she leaned forward to give it a pat on the cheek, and sat down to supper, declaring it to be the best face in the world.
column3: Opening her eyes again, and seeing her husband's face across the table, she leaned forward to give it a pat on the cheek, and sat down to supper, declaring it to be the best face in the world.
